content.description: Can be climbed as a thin hands haul, or get licked by some good ol' layback. Route begins with some fun mantling up short, broken columns of basalt. The crux sits about halfway up the route at a small bulge. Look for sneaky feet and angular smears.
content.protection: 0.4 - 1, bring multiples of 0.5 & 0.75, no anchors at top. Route must be rapped and cleaned.
content.location: Most obvious line on the wall. Just right of the tree the route begins at the short, broken columns of basalt. The first 20ft consists of mantling up the basalt steps to get to the crack.

content.description: Tokatee Falls rests within the Umpqua National Forest, in southern Oregon's Cascade Range. It's about 117 miles Southwest from Bend, OR and 58 miles east of Roseburg. The rock consists of columnar basalt, in which several cracks occupy themselves.
